The Republican National Committee passed a resolution directing federal and state lawmakers to enact strong abortion restrictions and push the issue in 2024, according to a leading anti-abortion rights group, as the GOP continues its efforts to restrict abortion months after Roe v. Wade was overturned—despite most Americans supporting it remaining legal.
Anti- and pro-abortion rights supporters at the 50th annual March for Life rally on January 20 in ... [+] Washington, DC.Getty Images

Key Facts


The RNC passed a resolution at its winter meeting directing lawmakers in Congress and state legislatures “to pass the strongest pro-life legislation possible” ahead of the 2024 election cycle—citing six-week abortion bans as an example—according to a copy of the resolution published by the anti-abortion rights SBA Pro-Life America.



Republican candidates are also directed to “go on offense in the 2024 election cycle” by attacking Democrats and their “extreme” positions on abortion rights.



RNC Committeewoman Tamara Scott, who sponsored the resolution, called attacking abortion rights a “key ingredient for GOP victory in 2024” in a statement issued by SBA.



The resolution slammed Republicans’ approach on abortion in the 2022 midterms—in which many candidates backtracked on anti-abortion stances and even changed their websites to tone down their views—criticizing candidates for not “fighting back and exposing Democratic extremism on abortion.”


The resolution was cheered by anti-abortion advocates, with SBA President Marjorie Dannenfelser saying in a statement it sends a “bold message” to Republicans.


The RNC has not yet responded to a request for further comment on the resolution.




What To Watch For
SBA has previously identified Virginia, North Carolina, Florida and Nebraska as the states they’re targeting to pass further abortion restrictions and bans next, though an effort to pass a 15-week abortion ban in Virginia has already been thwarted by its majority-Democratic state legislature. Republicans in the House have already introduced and passed some abortion restrictions now that they have a narrow majority, but any anti-abortion rights bills are expected to fail in the Democratic-controlled Senate, and would be vetoed by President Joe Biden even if passed.
Big Number
60%. That’s the share of Americans who believe abortion should be legal in all or most cases, according to a NPR/Ipsos poll conducted in January. The poll also found a 69% majority of respondents want abortion policy in their state to be decided by voters through ballot measures rather than state legislatures, with approximately half of both Democrats and Republicans reporting they disapprove of how their state’s legislature has handled abortion over the past year.

Chief Critic
“In 2022, voters resoundingly rejected anti-abortion politicians and made it clear that we do not want lawmakers controlling our bodies. Yet the RNC’s response is to double down and make a national abortion ban a part of the party platform,” Jenny Lawson, executive director of Planned Parenthood Votes, said in a statement Monday. “Every candidate will be held accountable to this out-of-touch agenda.”
Key Background
The debate over abortion rights has ramped up in the months since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June, as Republican-led states across the country have banned the procedure and debated new restrictions even as polling consistently shows a majority of Americans want it to remain legal. Six ballot measures in the midterm elections (including an August election in Kansas) came out in favor of abortion rights, and Americans’ opposition to the court’s ruling has been cited as a reason why Republicans failed to secure the “red wave” of GOP wins that had been anticipated. The RNC resolution is part of a broader effort by Republicans to continue to push abortion restrictions in the wake of the midterms anyway, however. House Republicans made multiple anti-abortion rights bills some of their first priorities after taking control of the chamber in January, and state lawmakers have introduced a slew of new bills restricting the procedure as legislatures have convened this month, particularly around restricting abortion pills.
Surprising Fact
Anti-abortion rights lawmakers have even suggested they may be willing to push restrictions in states where voters have signaled they support abortion rights through ballot measures. A bill introduced in Kansas tries to get around a court ruling protecting abortion rights statewide by allowing towns and counties to ban the procedure individually, even after 59% of the state’s voters rejected its anti-abortion ballot measure in August.
